turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm thinking of joining this hackathon, but I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed. It's my first one. Any advice on where to even start?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Hi there! That's great you're considering a hackathon! It can be overwhelming at first. My top recommendations are to start by thoroughly reviewing the hackathon's theme and rules, then brainstorm potential project ideas aligned with your skills and interests. Forming a team beforehand can also be beneficial.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, thanks! I think I have some ideas, but I'm worried about the tech stack. They mentioned AI/ML, but I'm not an expert. Is it even worth participating if I'm not a pro in that area?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: It's definitely still worth participating! Hackathons are about learning and experimenting. Focus on using your existing skills and explore how you can incorporate AI/ML concepts, even in a simple way. Many frameworks offer easy-to-use APIs. You could also team up with someone who has more AI/ML experience.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: That's reassuring! But what if my project idea is too similar to existing solutions? How do I ensure I'm not just copying something already out there, especially when AI/ML is involved - seems like everything's been done before!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid concern. Focus on adding a unique twist or applying the existing solutions to a new problem domain. Consider how you can tailor the solution to a specific niche or improve the user experience. Even if the core idea exists, your implementation and specific use case can make your project stand out. For example, if other image classifiers exist, perhaps yours is tailored to a very specific type of image, or has a novel user interface.
